Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic nuclear polarization at 7 Tesla to enable and enhance the study of chemical structures and surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professor Song-I Han at the University of California-Santa Barbara to pursue the development of advanced instrumentation and methodologies to exploit solid-state dynamic nuclear polarization (ssDNP) enhancement at 7 Tesla and liquid helium temperatures to significantly enhance the nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) signal. The proposed research activities is desigend to provide up to 4 to 5 orders of magnitudes of NMR signal enhancement. If successful, this new apparatus will enable characterization of interfaces and surfaces in a way not feasible before. Consequently, the largest impact of the proposed research lies in the characterization of chemical systems and materials of interest to society; namley, catalysts and energy-related and/or biocompatible materials. The proposed research also offers interdisciplinary training opportunities to next generation graduate and undergraduate students by providing them with hands-on experience in technology and hardware development from the ground up.

The overarching research goal is to advance ssDNP-enhanced NMR as a chemical characterization tool, with the focus on resolving local signatures of nanometer-scale domains and solid surfaces, where chemical processes occur and that are critical for material function. The intellectual merit of the proposed work is to address fundamental roadblocks in and mechanisms of ssDNP performance via studies of the temperature and microwave power dependence of DNP enhancements, frequency profiles and build-up time curves, as well as electron and nuclear spin relaxation times. Contemporary chemical systems from nanostructured hydrogels, mesoporous catalysts to supported catalysts will be studied, with the aim of selectively characterizing surface signatures and spatially heterogeneous solute/solvent composition. The prospect for DNP to transform NMR from offering atomistic details, but averaged over the entire sample into a surface sensitive and selective tool, is promising.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcome covering the lifetime of this award is the establishment of an instrumental with solid-state source powered broad-band (>10 GHz) dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) capabilities with concurrent electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) detection, arbitrary waveform generation (AWG), and two frequency pump-probe electron double resonance (ELDOR) capabilities. No other DNP instrument operating at high field at or above 7 Tesla to date offers a more versatile and comprehensive suite of tuning and diagnostic capabilities for DNP, including wide frequency tuning, AWG pulse shaping, EPR detection and ELDOR. The intellectual merit of the development include exciting scientific discoveries on the mechanism of cross-effect (CE) DNP, polarization transfer pathway and rates, depolarization mechanism under MAS, revealing that the extent of depolarization dominantly correlates with electron spin T1e, that the apparent Overhauser DNP effect can be a disguised truncated CE, and that broad-band AWG and tunable excitation can permit DNP analysis with transition metals conventionally outside the accessible range for DNP. The premise of this development is that great breakthroughs in magnetic resonance are often associated with change in operation from monochromatic CW to AWG-modulated operation that enables intricate manipulations and detection of the spin systems. The broader impact of this grant is the development of a novel instrumental platform that allows for the exploration and testing of novel DNP and EPR concepts and applications in fields beyond the current DNP community to questions in quantum information science to molecular magnetism. The here pursued activities will also impact the potential commercialization of instrumental platforms inspired by the developments achieved with this grant. Finally, the activities of this grant provided significant educational and professional development opportunities to more than four PhD students and three Postdoctoral researchers.
